title: Domain 1.3: Summarize cloud concepts and connectivity options.

A method to virtualize network services such as firewalls, load balancers, and routers, running them as software on standard hardware rather than dedicated appliances.

â˜ï¸ Virtual Private Cloud (VPC)

A private network within a public cloud where you can isolate resources, control traffic flow, and connect securely to your on-premises infrastructure.

ğŸ”’ Network Security Groups

Sets of security rules in cloud environments that control inbound and outbound traffic to virtual machines (VMs) or resources within a VPC.

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Network Security Lists

Similar to security groups but applied to subnets within a VPCâ€”used to define rules that allow or block traffic based on IP addresses and ports.

ğŸŒ Cloud Gateways

ğŸŒ Internet Gateway

Provides a path for traffic between a VPC and the internet, enabling public access to resources within the VPC.

ğŸ”„ Network Address Translation (NAT) Gateway

Translates private IP addresses to public ones (and vice versa), allowing private resources in a VPC to access the internet securely without exposing them directly.

ğŸŒ‰ Cloud Connectivity Options

ğŸŒ VPN

Virtual Private Network that establishes a secure and encrypted connection between a user or on-premises network and a cloud network.

ğŸ”Œ Direct Connect

A dedicated, private connection from an on-premises network to the cloud, providing more reliable and consistent performance than VPNs over the public internet.

âš–ï¸ Deployment Models

ğŸŒ Public

Resources are owned and operated by a cloud service provider, and shared with other tenants. The most common type of cloud environment.

ğŸ  Private

Resources are used exclusively by one organization. Can be hosted on-premises or by a third-party provider.

ğŸ”„ Hybrid

A combination of public and private clouds, allowing data and applications to be shared between them for greater flexibility.

ğŸ› ï¸ Service Models

ğŸŒ Software as a Service (SaaS)

Software applications hosted in the cloud and accessed through a web browser (e.g., Gmail, Office 365).

ğŸ–¥ï¸ Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)

Cloud services that provide computing resources like servers, storage, and networkingâ€”clients manage the operating system and applications (e.g., AWS EC2, Azure VMs).

ğŸ—ï¸ Platform as a Service (PaaS)

Cloud-based development platforms where developers can build, test, and deploy applications without managing the underlying hardware or software layers (e.g., Google App Engine, Azure App Service).

ğŸ“ˆ Scalability

The ability of a cloud environment to handle increased workloads by expanding resources (e.g., more VMs or storage) without affecting performance.

ğŸ”„ Elasticity

The ability of cloud resources to automatically scale up or down in response to workload demands, ensuring efficient use of resources.

ğŸ¢ Multitenancy

A cloud architecture where multiple customers (tenants) share the same infrastructure but maintain isolated resources. The same physical resources serve multiple customers.
